qas.question: What system also complements walking and biking?
What kind of priority zone has the city centre been transformed into?
What do bike paths go through to add enjoyment to the trip?
What is the layout of the neighbourhoods called?
How do people most often get to Strasbourg from elsewhere?
Who takes priority between pedestrians and bicyclists?
What is filtered out in the outer sections of Strausberg?
What adds enjoyment to doing a trip in the outer sections of Strausberg?
What system is used as a comprehensive layout beyond central Strasbourg?

context: The <a0_0>tram<a0_0/> system that now criss-crosses the historic city centre complements walking and biking in it. The centre has been transformed into a <a1_0>pedestrian<a1_0/> priority zone that enables and invites <b6_0>walking and <b5_0>biking<b6_0/><b5_0/> by making these active modes of transport comfortable, safe and enjoyable. These attributes are accomplished by applying the principle of "filtered permeability" to the existing irregular network of streets. It means that the network adaptations favour active transportation and, selectively, "filter out" the <b4_0>car<b4_0/> by reducing the number of streets that run through the centre. While certain streets are discontinuous for cars, they connect to a network of pedestrian and bike paths which permeate the entire centre. In addition, these paths go through <a2_0><b7_0>public squares<a2_0/> and open spaces<b7_0/> increasing the enjoyment of the trip. This logic of filtering a mode of transport is fully expressed in a comprehensive model for laying out neighbourhoods and districts – <b8_0>the <a3_0>Fused Grid<b8_0/><a3_0/>.
